We aim to focus on intuition and examples in these notes, following the work of Bott and Tu in[1].We will begin with defining and computing examples for the de Rham cohomology on Euclidean space. Then, on functions sends -forms to their gradients, on -forms maps -forms to their curl (when considering them as vector fields), and on -forms acts by sending the -form to the divergence of its associated vector field. Geometrically, an element of the -th de Rham cohomology of is represented by a cohomology class of closed -forms, which differ only by exact forms. One can think of the closed forms as being differential equations in a precise sense. Note that we could have made these definitions for any open subset, , obtaining a resulting complex with associated de Rham cohomology, .In general, the de Rham cohomology of is relatively easy to compute.
